titleStmt.title: Running head: REPITITION BIAS IN INTERTEMPORAL CHOICE

analytic.title: Running head: REPITITION BIAS IN INTERTEMPORAL CHOICE

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Intertemporal choices (i.e., the choice between a sooner available but smaller reward and a later available but larger reward) were initially thought to reflect stable preferences for immediate or delayed rewards. However, recently it has been shown that intertemporal choices are influenced by factors such as context variables and attentional processes. Here, we investigate if another factor, the choice repetition bias, affects decision making and attentional processes in intertemporal choice. The choice repetition bias is characterised by the tendency to repeat previous choices and to be slower when switching to an alternative choice. In a series of two experiments (including a pre-registered, eye-tracking study), we find that the choice repetition bias exists in intertemporal choice, but that it is not reflected in attentional biases towards the previous choice option or corresponding attributes. This finding raises interesting questions about the cognitive processes underlying the choice repetition bias. In addition, we successfully replicate other attentional effects from the intertemporal choice literature (e.g., more fixations on monetary dimension, gaze cascade effect).

div.p: conceptualization, methodology, writing-review & editing; SS: conceptualization, funding acquisition, supervision, writing-review & editing

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In everyday life, we frequently have to make decisions on multiple time scales. When investing money, for example, we must choose between the anticipated long-term increase in value (via interests) and the current value of the money. Such decisions are investigated in the lab in intertemporal choice (or delay discounting) tasks. Intertemporal choice tasks offer choices between smaller, but sooner available rewards (e.g., 10€ now; small/soon option) and larger, but later available rewards (e.g., 20€ in 2 months; large/late option). Typically, the preference for the large/late option decreases with longer delay (usually termed temporal or delay discounting; Loewenstein & Prelec, 1992). At first, it was proposed that selecting the large/late option requires self-control, as evidenced by longer response times and greater activation of prefrontal brain regions (McClure et al., 2004). Additionally, it was thought that these preferences for certain choices were consistent within individuals (Kable, 2013;McClure et al., 2004). However, more recently, this has been questioned by findings indicating that decision making in intertemporal choice tasks is more variable and depends on various context factors (for an overview, see Lempert & Phelps, 2016), and that it reflects value comparison rather than self control and should hence be seen as a form of value-based decision making (Bulley et al., 2022).

In addition, eye-tracking studies have revealed that different information search strategies, attentional biases, and random fluctuations in attention also play a role in decision making in intertemporal choice (Amasino et al., 2019;Fisher, 2021;Franco-Watkins et al., 2016;He et al., 2023;Khaw et al., 2018;Reeck et al., 2017). In this paper, we focus on another factor that might impact intertemporal choice if seen as value-based decision making: bias from previous decisions, or more specifically, choice repetition biases. The choice repetition bias (i.e., the tendency to repeat the previous choice and to perform choice repetitions faster than choice switches) has been long established in perceptual decision tasks (Bertelson, 1961;Bonaiuto et al., 2016;Cho et al., 2002;Gao et al., 2009;Remington, 1969;Soetens et al., 1985;Urai et al., 2019) and has recently also been demonstrated in value-based decision tasks (Chung et al., 2023;Herranz-Zarzoso et al., 2020;. Here, we ask if this bias can also be found in intertemporal choice. We further use eye-tracking to gain insights into the underlying attentional processes and to replicate some of the attentional effects reported in the literature (see below).

div.head: Choice repetition bias as potential influence on intertemporal choice
div.p: The choice repetition bias is thought to emerge from residual activation from the previous trial (Bertelson, 1961;Soetens et al., 1985). This is supported by neural network models (Bonaiuto et al., 2016;Cho et al., 2002;Gao et al., 2009;Rustichini & Padoa-Schioppa, 2015;Scherbaum et al., 2016) and by neural recordings in monkeys (Padoa-Schioppa, 2013;Padoa-Schioppa & Assad, 2006. In intertemporal choice, this would mean that choosing the small/soon option in the previous trial would either make it more likely to choose the small/soon option again or lead to longer response times when choosing the large/late option instead. To our knowledge, this has not yet been tested in intertemporal choice tasks. Our reasoning rests on two observations.

First, repetition effects have been found in other value-based decision tasks (i.e., tasks where decisions are not based on objective evidence, but rather on individual subjective values assigned to the decision options) (Chung et al., 2023;. For example, in several previous studies we used a gamified decision task where participants had to accumulate points in a limited amount of time. To gain points, participants had to repeatedly choose between two coins that appeared in a two-dimensional world. One coin was always closer (i.e., faster to reach), but worth fewer points, and one coin was further away (i.e., slower to reach), but worth more points. Hence, participants were required to make a trade-off between the amount of time they engaged in reaching each option and the corresponding points they could earn. Using this gamified decision task, we showed that participants had a tendency to repeat their choices and that choice repetitions were faster than choice switches (Scherbaum et al., 2016(Scherbaum et al., , 2018(Scherbaum et al., , 2022Schoemann & Scherbaum, 2020b;. Since our task has significant similarities to intertemporal choice, namely in terms of the trade-off between different attributes and the discounting of reward values by time, we believe that similar effects might be plausible in intertemporal choice.

Second, intertemporal choice has been shown to be influenced by external and internal contexts (for an overview, see Lempert & Phelps, 2016). External contexts pertain to the structure of the intertemporal choice task that might impact the decision-making process, such as the way that the choice information is presented (e.g., Dshemuchadse et al., 2013;Fassbender et al., 2014;Magen et al., 2014;Radu et al., 2011;Read et al., 2005). For example, presenting the delay in an intertemporal choice task in the form of calendar dates (e.g., 17 November) instead of in the corresponding duration of days (e.g., 14 days) has been shown to increase the number of large/late choices (date-delay effect; e.g., DeHart & Odum, 2015;Dshemuchadse et al., 2013;Read et al., 2005). Internal contexts pertain to inner states of people that might impact the decision-making process. Lempert and Phelps (2016) speak of "incidental carryover effects" (p. 70) of internal contexts such as mood or stress. For example, some studies suggest that participants show a choice bias towards the small/soon option after being exposed to positive affective stimuli such as music (Zhou et al., 2022), videos of variety shows (Zhou et al., 2021), or erotic images (Van Den Bergh et al., 2008) (but also see Pyone & Isen, 2011 for opposite effects). Here, the choice repetition bias might be another type of internal context. A participant might approach the same choice from different contexts depending on their previous choice (i.e., a small/soon choice in the previous decision might induce a different context than a large/late choice in the previous decision) and incidentally carry over their previous preference to the choice at hand.

div.head: Attentional processes in intertemporal choice
div.p: If there is a choice repetition bias in intertemporal choice, it raises the question of how this bias affects the decision-making process. A plausible candidate for a mechanism could be attentional processes. People might exhibit either an option-based (where they focus on the same option they chose in the previous trial) or a dimension-based attentional repetition bias (where they focus on the dimension that favoured their previous choice, such as the monetary dimension after making large/late choices, or the temporal dimension after making small/soon choices).

This presumption is supported by influential work demonstrating that attentional processes are highly important in decision making (Bhatnagar & Orquin, 2022;Orquin & Mueller Loose, 2013), and computational models have strongly benefited from incorporating attention in addition to, for instance, the sequential sampling principle, when modelling preferential choice (Turner et al., 2018). Initially attention was incorporated as a latent, stochastic variable in such models (Busemeyer et al., 2019;Turner et al., 2018), but direct measures of visual attention via eye-tracking have recently been proven to be very informative to uncover the decision-making process and to predict choice (Ashby et al., 2016;Cavanagh et al., 2014;Colas, 2017;Fisher, 2017;Gluth et al., 2018Gluth et al., , 2020Smith & Krajbich, 2018, 2019Thomas et al., 2019Thomas et al., , 2021Towal et al., 2013) (for a review, see Krajbich, 2019). From the more experimental side, a large body of studies has even pointed to a causal effect of attention on choices in many domains (Armel et al., 2008;Ghaffari & Fiedler, 2018;Kunar et al., 2017;Lim et al., 2011;Milosavljevic et al., 2012;Pärnamets et al., 2015;Shimojo et al., 2003).

In light of these findings, it seems plausible that the choice repetition bias impacts attentional processes. The previous choice might shift attention towards the respective option (i.e., more visual attention on the small/soon option after a small/soon choice) or towards the more favourable attribute dimension (i.e., more visual attention on the temporal dimension after small/soon choices). In fact, an increasing number of eye-tracking studies has shown attentional processes in to play a role in how attentional preferences and biases impact decision making in intertemporal choice. Specifically, three effects are of interest here: an attentional bias towards the monetary over the temporal dimension, the impact of relative attentional preference for one of the choice options (i.e., participants choose the option that they look at more frequently), and that the last fixation predicts choice (so-called gaze cascade effect [Shimojo et al., 2003]). A caveat in the first studies showing these effects (Franco-Watkins et al., 2016) is that the positions of the choice options were fixed within participants, creating a potential confound between attentional choice biases and reading direction (Khaw et al., 2018), which is why new studies using eye-tracking with intertemporal choices should vary the position of choice options.

div.head: Research aims
div.p: In this paper, we investigate if the choice repetition bias exist in intertemporal choice tasks and how this is reflected in attentional processes indicated by eye movements.

Furthermore, we aim to replicate the existing eye-tracking findings in intertemporal choices. We report two experiments in which we presented individualized trials intended to elicit either a bias toward the small/soon or large/late option in the following trial and measured how this affected the following trial with regard to choice, response time, and eye movement. Experiment 1 is a pilot study without eye-tracking to establish the choice repetition effects with our experimental procedure (i.e., higher proportion of choice repetitions and faster response times for repetitions than for switches). Experiment 2 is the pre-registered main study where we use eye-tracking to uncover attentional processes based on visual fixations. We expect that fixations patterns would be influenced by the previous choice. Specifically, we hypothesise that the previous choice should induce an attentional bias towards the attribute dimension that favoured the respective choice in the previous trial (i.e., a small/soon choice biases attention towards the temporal dimension, whereas a large/late choice biases attention towards the monetary dimension). In addition, we aim to replicate the previous attentional choice biases in intertemporal choice (Franco-Watkins et al., 2016), namely the attentional preference towards the monetary dimension, the gaze cascade effect, that attentional preference predicts choice and that choosing the delayed option takes longer deliberation time.

div.head: Experiment 1: Behavioural pilot study
div.p: Experiment 1 serves to establish the choice repetition bias and to function as a pilot study for the main eye-tracking study. Specifically, we expect to find effects of choice repetition on choice level and on response time level. We also aim to investigate if and how the strength of the bias trial affects choice repetition. Further, we hypothesised that participants have longer response times when choosing the large/late option over the small/soon option.

div.head: Methods
div.p: Participants. We did not conduct a power analysis because we did not have specific expectations for the size of the effect. We recruited 21 participants through the participant database of TU Dresden, Germany (mean age = 30.18 years, SD = 10.68 years; 7 female). All participants had normal or corrected-to-normal vision. They received either course credits or 5€/hour for their participation, as well as a payout based on one of their choices in the intertemporal choice task (either 4€ now or 5€ in 10 days). The study was approved by the university's ethics committee (EK 493112015).
Study procedure. Participants first gave informed consent, underwent a vision check and completed a demographic questionnaire. Then, they performed the intertemporal choice task.

The task started with instructions and a tutorial of 16 trials. Participants were informed that one random decision trial would be selected to be paid out at the end of the study to make each decision relevant to them. Due to practicability reasons, we used a pre-selected trial for this payout. The intertemporal choice task was split into two parts: A measurement part intended to measure participants' individual temporal discounting and a choice bias part with individually tailored trials intended to induce choice biases. In each trial, participants had 4 s to make their decision. The inter-trial interval was randomly jittered between 750 to 1000 ms. Participants had one break during the measurement part and three breaks during the choice bias part. After the experiment, participants were asked to rate the difficulty of eight trials and then completed a follow-up questionnaire. Overall, the experiment took approximately 1 hour.

Apparatus and Stimuli. We used Psychtoolbox version 3 (Kleiner et al., 2007) in Matlab 2018b running on a Windows 10 computer. Participants made their responses by pressing keys ('x' for left, ',' for right) on a QWERTZ-layout keyboard. The experiment was presented on a 24 inch computer screen with a resolution of 1920 x 1080 pixels and a refresh rate of 72 Hz.

The distance from participants to the screen was approximately 60 cm. The stimuli were black text (Courier, font size 30) presented on a white background. Each stimulus consisted of a number with two decimals places in one line and the unit (either euros or days) in the line below.

The stimuli were positioned in four quadrants of the screen as presented in Figure 1, with a vertical distance between the centre of the stimuli of 468 pixels and a horizontal distance of 470 pixels. In the centre of the screen, a black fixation cross appeared in between trials (60 x 60 pixels). Within each trial, a shrinking teal-coloured square represented the time that participants had left to make their decision (size continuously decreasing from 80 x 80 pixels to 0 x 0 pixels).

Intertemporal choice task. The intertemporal choice task consisted of a binary choice between one option that was smaller in value, but available sooner (small/soon option) and one option that was larger in value, but available later (large/late option). The task had two parts: The measurement part (designed to capture individual delay discounting) and the choice bias part (designed to induce and measure choice biases).

In the measurement part, we presented a range of different small/soon and large/late options. In each trial, the value of the large/late option was randomly drawn from a range of 19.00€ to 21.00€ in steps of 0.50€ and the delay of the small/soon option was randomly drawn from a range of 0 to 7 days. We systematically varied the value of the small/soon option and the delay of the large/late option. The value of the small/soon option was either 20, 50, 75, 85, 90, 93, 95 or 97% of the value of the large/late option (rounded to the closest .00 or .50). The large/late option had an additional delay with regards to the small/soon option of 3, 5, 10, 20, 35, 60 or 90 days. The manipulation of large/late delay and small/soon value yielded 56 trials, which we repeated three times. We also included two payout trials (where the small/soon option had a delay of either 0 or 1 days and a value of 4.00€, and the large/late option had a delay of either 10 or 11 days and a value of 5.00€). All trials were presented in randomized order. Monetary values were displayed as numbers with two decimal places and the unit euro; temporal values were displayed as integers with the unit days ("Tage" in German). In the centre of the screen, a green square appeared at the beginning of each trial. The square represented the time that was left in each trial (4 s time limit).

In the choice bias part, we used the data from the measurement part to estimate participants' individual delay discounting. This yielded participant-specific indifference points for each delay. Indifference points are the value ratio of small/soon to large/late where participants are equally likely to select the small/soon or the large/late option; they can be thought of as the discounted value of the large/late option at that delay (i.e., an indifference point of .80 for a delay of 7 days would mean that the large/late option is worth 80% of its actual value for that delay). A detailed description can be found in the supplement. We used these indifference points to create trials where participants would either prefer the small/soon option (strong small/soon bias: value of the small/soon option set to 0.3 above the indifference point; slight small/soon bias: 0.1 above indifference point), prefer the large/late option (strong large/late bias: value of the small/soon option set to 0.3 below the indifference point; slight large/late bias: 0.1 below indifference point), or be neutral (value of the small/soon option set to the indifference point) 1 . We built 112 mini-blocks of three trials where the first two trials were either both small/soon bias trials or both bias large/late trials (bias trials) and the third trial was always a neutral trial (target trial; for details see the supplement). We varied the strength of the second bias trial to be either a strong or a slight bias trial. A schematic overview can be found in Figure 2.

The position of the small/soon and large/late options varied within participants (left/right), whereas the position of the units (days and euros; top/bottom) stayed constant within participants and was balanced across participants. The units stayed present during the ITI so that participants knew where the monetary and the temporal information would be displayed, but were not able to predict where the small/soon and the large/late option would appear.

The large/late value and the small/soon delay of each trial was randomly drawn from the same value range as used in the measurement part (19.00 to 21.00€ and 0 to 7 days, respectively). The value of the small/soon option depended on the trial type (small/soon trial: indifference point + 0.1/0.3; large/late trial: indifference point -0.1/0.3; neutral trial: indifference point). The delay of the large/late option was selected randomly in each trial from a pool of values that was adapted to each participants' indifference points. Hence, from the full potential range of 3 to 90 days, only delays were included in the pool where the indifference point allowed for the respective manipulation of a distance to the indifference point of +/-0.3. Figure 2: Overview of the experimental manipulation and procedure of the choice bias part of the intertemporal choice task. In both the pilot and the main study, trials were organized in mini-blocks of three blocks. In each mini-block, the first two trials served as bias trials and either favoured the small/soon (SS) or large/late (LL) option. The third trial served as the target trial and was neutral. After some mini-blocks, a catch trial was presented that included a soon/large (SL) option. In the pilot study, we additionally varied the strength of the second bias trial (strong vs. slight, see grey box), whereas in the main study, we only used strong bias trials.

We also included 17 catch trials (6 trials in the measurement part, 11 trials in the choice bias part) where one option was available sooner and had a larger value, therefore making it the correct choice. Participants largely chose correctly, only failing 0.81 catch trials on average (SD = 0.93 trials, range: 0 to 3 trials).

Data processing and statistical analyses. We used Matlab R2021b (The MathWorks Inc.) for data processing and R 4.2.1 (R Core Team, 2022) for data analysis and plotting. We plotted the data via raincloud plots using the ggrain package (Judd et al., 2023). In these plots, violin plots represent the kernel density estimate, boxplots represent the median response, dots represent mean values of individual participants and lines connect participants' values in different conditions. All hypotheses focused on the target trials in the choice bias part of the experiment. For choice repetition analyses, we focused on target trials after successful bias trials (i.e., where participants chose the small/soon option in small/soon bias trials or the large/late option in large/late bias trials). We log-transformed response times.

Data statement. We report how we determined our sample size, all data exclusions (if any), all manipulations, and all measures in the study. The study was not preregistered. All data and analysis scripts are available at https://osf.io/zp6er/.

div.head: Results
div.p: All descriptive statistics can be found in Table 1.

First, we checked if participants showed a repetition bias in their choices and in their response times. We compared the proportion of large/late choices in neutral target trials after small/soon bias trials and large/late bias trials using a one-tailed t-test and found that participants chose the large/late option significantly more often, t(20) = 2.57, p = .009, dz = 0.56 (see Figure 3A). Participants also had longer response times when their choices in target trials where a switch (as compared to a repetition) from the previous choice, t(20) = 3.99, p < .001, dz = 0.87 (see Figure 3B). In addition, we tested if the repetition bias effect was influenced by the strength of the bias trial. However, we did not find a significant effect of bias strength (for details, see supplement). Finally, we tested if response times were longer for large/late target choices as compared to small/soon target choices. A one-tailed t-test did not show a significant difference, t(20) = 1.59, p = .06, dz = 0.35 (see Figure 3C). However, since large/late response times were descriptively longer and the p-value was close to significance, it was also possible that this was an effect of low power due to the small sample size of the pilot study. Hence, we still expected this effect to be significant with a bigger sample size.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In Experiment 1, we found a choice repetition bias in intertemporal choice: Participants repeated their choices and were slower when switching from a previous choice than when repeating a previous choice. We also observed a trend towards slower response times in large/late choices, which might not have reached significance due to the small sample size. with eye-tracking. Based on Experiment 1 and the literature, we derive hypotheses regarding the choice repetition bias and general attentional processes (preregistered at https://osf.io/5nuqs).

div.head: Choice repetition bias
div.p: H1) We expect a higher proportion of large/late target choices after a large/late-biased sequence than after a small/soon-biased sequence.

div.head: H2)
div.p: We expect response times in target choices to be longer when participants switch from the choice in the previous bias trials as compared to repeating that choice.

div.head: H3)
div.p: We expect the choice in the bias trial to affect attentional preference in the subsequent target trial (i.e., more fixations on the small/soon option after a small/soon bias trial). H4) In target trials, we expect an attentional bias towards the temporal dimension after small/soon bias trials and to the monetary dimension after large/late bias trials.

div.head: Attentional processes
div.p: H5) We expect a higher amount of fixations on the monetary dimension than on the temporal dimension.

div.head: H6)
div.p: We expect attentional preferences for the small/soon or large/late option to predict choice, as indicated by fixation frequencies for the small/soon and large/late option. H7) We expect the last fixated option to predict choice.

div.head: H8)
div.p: We expect longer response times for large/late choices than for small/soon choices.

div.head: Methods
div.p: The methods were largely similar to Experiment 1; hence, we only list the details where Experiment 2 differed from Experiment 1.

Participants. We used GPower (Faul et al., 2007) to determine our target sample size based on Experiment 1, where dz = 0.35 was the smallest effect size of interest. We needed 51 participants to detect this effect in a one-tailed paired t-test (α = .05, 1-β = .80). We recruited 85 participants over the participant data base of TU Dresden. 21 participants were excluded after an initial measurement part due to extreme discounting patterns and four participants were excluded due to technical issues with the eye-tracker. Of the remaining 60 participants, we excluded six participants because they failed more than two out of 16 catch trails and we excluded one participant due to technical issues with data recording. The final sample consisted of 53 participants (mean age = 23.66 years, SD = 4.35 years; 38 female). Participants received 8€/hour or course credit as well as additional payment based on one of their actual choices (see study procedure below). The study was approved by the university's ethics committee (EK 493112015).
Study procedure. The study procedure was the same as in Experiment 1 with the addition of eye-tracking.

Intertemporal choice task. There were two minor changes to the intertemporal choice task presented in Experiment 1. First, the delay of the large/late option varied in a range of 3 to 60 days instead of 3 to 90 days. Second, we only included strong bias trials in the choice bias part of the experiment instead of varying the bias strength, as we did not find an effect of bias strength in Experiment 1.

In addition, the positions of the small/soon and large/late option during the choice bias part were not fully balanced due to a programming error. In target trials, the positions stayed the same as in the previous trial in case of a small/soon sequence and were swapped in case of a large/late sequence. However, since the positions of the options randomly varied for the bias trials, this meant that positions were still varied for all target trials. Based on extensive additional analyses, we do not believe that this had any impact on our results (for more details, see the supplement).

Eye-tracking. For eye-tracking, we used an Eyelink 1000 desk-mounted system (SR Research, Ontario, Canada) to track the right pupil with a sample rate of 500 Hz. Participants' head position was fixed using a chin rest. Before the intertemporal choice task, the eye-tracker was calibrated to nine fixation points on the screen using the Eyelink 1000 software. During the breaks between experimental blocks, a drift check was performed to check calibration quality; if necessary, the eye tracker was re-calibrated at that point.

Data processing and statistical analyses. We used Matlab R2021b for data processing and R 4.2.1 (R Core Team, 2022) for statistical analyses. All statistical analyses were ran with α = .05. We used the lme4 (Bates et al., 2015) package for mixed effects analyses. We ran linear mixed effect models with a Gaussian distribution for continuous outcome variables, a Poisson distribution for discrete outcome variables, and a binomial distribution using a logit link for binary outcome variables. We tested both random-intercept as well as random-intercept-randomslope models for each analysis and determined the best fitting model via Likelihood Ratio test (if both models converged); the random-intercept-random-slope models always outperformed their random-intercept counterparts. We grand-mean centred all metric predictors and dummy-coded categorical predictors. For hypotheses that were tested using t-tests, we additionally ran mixed effects models as exploratory analyses. All statistics can be found in Table S4 in the Supplement.

All hypotheses, except for Hypotheses 5, 6, and 7, focused on target trials in the choice bias part. For choice repetition analyses, we focused on target trials after successful bias trials (i.e., where participants chose the small/soon option in small/soon bias trials or the large/late option in large/late bias trials). We log-transformed response times.

We imported eye-tracking data into Matlab using the Edf2Mat toolbox (Adrian Etter, https://github.com/uzh/edf-converter/). For eye-tracking data, we defined areas of interest (AOIs) around the stimulus boxes with margins of 38 pixels (appr. 1° visual angle; Orquin et al., 2016).

Consecutive fixations to the same AOI were counted as one fixation. We included fixations on AOIs that started before the trial began or ended after the response. We used fixation frequencies to calculate the Selection Bias (SB) (Franco-Watkins et al., 2016) as follows:

where nFix is the number of fixations. The SB was 1 if all fixations were on small/soon AOIs, 0 if there was an equal number of fixations on small/soon and large/late AOIs, and -1 if all fixations were on large/late AOIs.

Data statement. We report how we determined our sample size, all data exclusions (if any), all manipulations, and all measures in the study. The study (including hypotheses and analyses) was preregistered at https://osf.io/5nuqs. All data and analysis scripts are available at https://osf.io/zp6er/.

div.head: Choice repetition bias
div.p: All descriptive statistics are presented in Table 2. We hypothesised that participants would show a repetition bias, as indexed by a higher proportion of large/late choices in target trials after large/late bias trials as compared to small/soon bias trials (Hypothesis 1) as well as shorter response times for choice repetitions in target trials as compared to switches (Hypothesis 2). We tested both hypotheses with one-tailed paired t-tests. Our analyses confirmed both hypothesis. Participants chose the large/late option more often after large/late bias trials (as compared to small/soon bias trials), t(52) = 4.65, p < .001, dz = 0.64, and their response times were faster when their choice was a repetition of the previous choice, t(52) = 4.00, p < .001, dz = 0.55 (see Figure 4). Mixed effect models confirmed both the choice repetition bias, b = 0.54, OR = 1.72, z = 5.54, p < .001, and the effect on response times, b = 0.03 (with b0 = 0.649), t = 3.38, p < .001. Hence, the chance of choosing the large/late option was higher by a factor of 1.72 after small/soon bias trials) and repetitions were on average 58 ms faster than switches.

Next, we tested if the choice repetition bias is also reflected in the attentional processes during decision making. First, we hypothesised that the choices in bias trials would affect attentional preferences in target trials (Hypothesis 3). Specifically, we tested if the bias trial was able to predict the selection bias score in the subsequent target trial using a paired one-sample ttest. Against our hypothesis, we did not find a significant difference between selection bias scores after large/late and after small/soon bias trials, t(52) = 0.22, p = .41, dz = 0.03 (see Figure 5A). A mixed effects analysis supported this finding, b = 0.004, t = 0.45, p = .66. Hence, the choice bias did not affect attentional preferences to the small/soon or large/late option in the next trial. Second, we hypothesised that, in target trials, participants would show an attentional bias towards the temporal dimension after small/soon bias trials and an attentional preference towards the monetary dimension after large/late bias trials (Hypothesis 4). We tested this using two separate paired one-tailed t-tests on the number of fixations on time AOIs vs. value AOIs. While we did find a significantly greater number of fixations on the monetary dimension as compared to the temporal dimension for trials after large/late bias, t(52) = 4.16, p < .001, dz = 0.57, we did not find a significantly greater number of fixations on the temporal dimension after small/soon bias, t(52) = -3.52, p = 1, dz = -0.35 (see Figure 5B). Two mixed effects models with the predictor dimension (time, value) for each bias type (SS, LL) supported these findings, revealing significant effects of dimension that, importantly, went in the same direction (i.e., both predicted a higher number of fixations for the monetary dimension; SS bias: b = 0.12, z = 3.11, p = .002;
LL bias: b = 0.18, z = 4.36, p < .001). In conclusion, participants showed a general attentional bias towards the monetary dimension that was not influenced by the choice in the preceding trial.

div.head: Attentional choice biases
div.p: All descriptive statistics can be found in Table 3. First, we focused on effects within trials. We expected participants to pay more attention to the monetary dimension than to the temporal dimension (Hypothesis 5). We tested this with a one-tailed paired t-test on the number of fixations on monetary AOIs and on temporal AOIs. The test confirmed our hypothesis, t(52) = 3.84, p < .001, dz = 0.53, as did a mixed effect model, b = 0.14, z = 3.70, p < .001. Hence, the number of fixations was on average higher by 0.35 for the monetary compared to the temporal dimension (see Figure 6A).

Further, we predicted that choices would be associated with attentional preferences for the small/soon and for the large/late option (selection bias, Hypothesis 6) and by the last fixation before the response (gaze cascade effect, Hypothesis 7). We tested this using generalized mixed effects models with a logit link function on the criterion choice (SS/LL). For the attentional preference hypothesis, we used the predictor selection bias (ratio of small/soon to large/late fixations, with 1 indicating solely small/soon fixations, 0 indicating an equal proportion of fixations on both options, and -1 indicating solely large/late fixations). The analysis revealed that, as expected, the selection bias predicted choice, b = 3.31, OR = 27.39, z = 13.16, p < .001 (see Figure 6B). Hence, for each increase of the selection bias towards the SS option by 0.1, the odds of choosing the SS option over the LL option increased by a factor of 1.39. For the gaze cascade effect, we used the last fixation (SS/LL) as predictor and, as expected, found a significant effect, b = 0.85, OR = 2.33, z = 9.38, p < .001 (see Figure 6C). Hence, if the last fixation was on the SS option, the odds of choosing the SS option over the LL option increased by a factor of 2.33.

We further expected response times in target trials to be slower in large/late choices than in small/soon choices (Hypothesis 8). A one-tailed paired t-test did not confirm that hypothesis, t(51) = -1.92, p = .97, dz = -0.27 (see Figure 6D). An mixed effects model did not reveal a significant effect of choice type on response time, b = 0.03, t = -1.45, p = .116. An alternative hypothesis could be that participants have faster response times for the choice type that they have a preference for (Zhao et al., 2019); that is, faster response times for LL choices in case of an overall preference for LL choices and faster response times for SS choices in case of an overall preference for SS choices. We ran exploratory analyses that show support for this account (see Supplement).

As a sense check, we ran exploratory analyses comparing response times for neutral and SS/LL bias trials in the supplement, which showed that response times were longer in neutral target trials than in SS/LL bias trials (as the smaller difference in subjective value should make the decision more difficult, see e.g., Fisher, 2021;Lin et al., 2018). We also tested all eye-tracking hypotheses that focused on number of fixations with dwell time instead and found the same qualitative results (see Supplement).

div.head: Discussion
div.p: In Experiment 2, we replicated the choice repetition bias effects from our first experiment: Participants had a tendency to repeat their choices and they were slower when switching from their previous choice than when repeating their previous choice. Interestingly, we did not find any corresponding biases in the number of fixations. Hence, our results do not indicate that the choice repetition bias emerges due to changes in attentional processes. However, we successfully replicated other attentional biases previously reported in the intertemporal choice literature, such as more fixations on the monetary than the temporal dimension, the gazecascade effect and that attentional preferences predicted choice (i.e., participants chose the option they looked at more). We did not find the expected patterns for small/soon and large/late choice, with participants showing an attentional preference for the monetary dimension for both choices and no significant differences in response time.

div.head: General discussion
div.p: In this paper, we demonstrated that the choice repetition bias can also be found in intertemporal choice. Interestingly, this bias was not reflected in attentional processes. However, we replicated previously reported attentional effects in intertemporal choice, such as the gaze cascade effect and attentional preference to the monetary dimension.

div.head: Choice repetition bias in intertemporal choice
div.p: The choice repetition bias is characterised by a tendency to repeat previous choices and by faster decision making for choice repetitions compared to switches. Here, we found convincing evidence for these effects in an intertemporal choice task across two experiments. This is in line with similar effects reported for other value-based decision tasks (Chung et al., 2023;Herranz-Zarzoso et al., 2020;. We expected to see corresponding biases in attentional processes, such that participants would either show an option-based (where they focus on the same option they chose in the previous trial) or a dimension-based (where they focus on the dimension that favoured their previous choice, such as the monetary dimension after making large or late choices, or the temporal dimension after making small or soon choices) attentional repetition bias. However, we found no evidence for any of such attentional repetition bias. We see two possible explanations for this finding. First, choice repetition biases might simply not have any effects on overt attention. Behavioural evidence and computational modelling suggest that the choice repetition bias emerges due to residual activation from the previous trial (Bertelson, 1961;Cho et al., 2002;Gao et al., 2009;Senftleben et al., 2020;Soetens et al., 1984). This is supported by evidence from studies with monkeys showing that neural activity in the orbitofrontal cortex reflects the influence of previous choices in value-based decision tasks (Padoa-Schioppa, 2013;Padoa-Schioppa & Assad, 2008;Rustichini & Padoa-Schioppa, 2015). One open question is on what level the choice repetition bias emerges: Is it a bias towards simply repeating the same motor response, or simply repeating the choice with similar sensory properties? Is it an attentional bias on the respective choice options or is it an inferential bias? A purely motoric bias can be ruled out, as choice repetition biases have been demonstrated even when position options are randomised and when different response modalities than simple key presses are used (Lade et al., 2016;Scherbaum et al., 2016;Schoemann & Scherbaum, 2020a). Likewise, we ruled out that choice repetition emerges because of a repetition of stimulus features in a previous study (Scherbaum et al., 2016); instead, we found that participants repeated the same choice category (e.g., the small/soon option) instead of repeating the choice with the same stimulus features. This leaves the question of how this bias towards the same choice category is enacted: Do people pay more attention towards the previously chosen option, thus allowing them to process this option more quickly or weighing the option information more heavily during the evidence sampling phase (Krajbich et al., 2012)?

The results of our present study would suggest that this is not the case, as we found a choice repetition bias on a behavioural level, but no indication of an attentional repetition bias on an option or attribute level. Instead, the choice repetition bias might occur purely during the inferential stage of decision making (Wyart & Koechlin, 2016) due to residual neural activation from the previous trial. Second, it is possible that choice repetition biases on overt attention exist, but were not captured in our task. This might be due to the contingent nature of the decision options: After participants became familiar with the overall range of values and delays, fixations on just the value or delay of one of the options might have already been enough to derive the relative value of each option heuristically. In that case, any attentional biases due to repetition effects might be too subtle to be reflected in overall fixation frequencies, which is admittedly a very abrasive measure of attentional processes. However, we also analysed dwell times in order to assess if the overall processing time of each option or attribute could predict choice repetition and did not find any evidence for an attentional repetition bias in that measure either. In addition, we were able to replicate several other attentional biases reported in the intertemporal choice literature (see below). We interpret this as an indication that our paradigm was able to produce typical attentional effects and should have been able to produce attentional repetition biases, if they existed.

div.head: Replication of attentional biases in intertemporal choice
div.p: There are several general attentional biases in intertemporal choice that have been reported in the literature. In particular, we aimed to replicate effects from Franco-Watkins and colleagues (2016), who were one of the first to use eye-tracking in intertemporal choice. One drawback of their study was that the location of the small/soon and large/late options was fixed, hence potentially confounding any attentional effect of decision making with effects of reading orientation (Khaw et al., 2018).

However, we replicated the finding that people pay more attention to the monetary dimension as compared to the temporal dimension, as indicated by a higher number of fixations (Franco-Watkins et al., 2016). We also replicated that relative attentional preferences during the decision-making process predict choice (i.e., participants have a higher likelihood of choosing the option that they look at more often during the decision-making process; Franco-Watkins et al., 2016). This finding connects well to other empirical findings showing that random fluctuations in attention affect choice (Fisher, 2021;Krajbich et al., 2010). Finally, we also replicated the so-called gaze cascade effect (i.e., participants have a higher likelihood of choosing the option that they look at last during the decision-making process; Shimojo et al., 2003), which has been shown in various other preferential and value-based decision tasks (Atalay et al., 2012;Mitsuda & Glaholt, 2014;Mullett & Stewart, 2016;Stewart et al., 2016), therefore suggesting that this attentional bias seems to be a general phenomenon in value-based decision making regardless of domain. This also ties in with other studies arguing that different types of decision making, such as intertemporal choice and risky choice, largely follow the same decision-making process and can be explained using the same decision making model (Luckman et al., 2018).

Finally, we expected processing of large/late choices to take longer and therefore lead to longer response times compared to small/soon choice. This follows from a dual process account of intertemporal choice where choosing the delayed large/late option requires self control to overcome the immediately rewarding small/soon choice (for a list of examples from the literature, see Bulley et al., 2022). However, both our experiments did not support this hypothesis. Descriptively, we found mixed effects, with slower response times for the large/late option in Experiment 1 and slower response times for the small/soon option in Experiment 2.

One explanation for this discrepancy is offered by Zhao and colleagues (2019). They showed that response times in intertemporal choice tasks are highly correlated with individual choice biases towards one option, such that people who have an overall preference for the small/soon option have faster response times in small/soon choices and people who have an overall preference for the large/late option have faster response times in large/late choices. This effect fits well with our data, as large/late choice percentages were generally higher in Experiment 1 than in Experiment 2 and we found a negative correlation between beta weights for a regression of response times on choice type and a general preference for the large/late option. This would suggest that there is no general difference in decision making between large/late and small/soon choices, but that differences in response times are more dependent on general preferences for one option.

div.head: Limitations
div.p: Due to a programming error in the eye-tracking study, the positions of the LL and SS options were not fully balanced as intended and preregistered for target trials. The options always swapped positions after SS bias trials and always remained in the same position after LL bias trials. While this did not affect overall position balancing (as the positions in the first bias trial were selected randomly), it does raise the concern that any choice repetition biases that we observed might have been caused by a motoric instead of a choice repetition bias. However, a follow-up analyses did not reveal any differences in choice repetition rate or response time switch costs after SS and LL bias trials (see Supplement), as would have been the case for a pure motor effect. In addition, the option positions were balanced correctly in Experiment 1, where we also found a choice repetition bias. This leads us to conclude that our results cannot be explained by a mere motoric repetition bias.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this study, we show that people demonstrate a choice repetition bias in intertemporal choice, that is, they have a tendency to repeat their previous choice and to show longer response times when switching to an alternative choice. Using eye-tracking, we find that this is not reflected in an attentional repetition bias, indicating that the choice repetition bias does not work through attentional processes. Further, we replicate other attentional biases in intertemporal choice, such as that relative attention predicts choice and that people pay more attention to the monetary than the temporal dimension. Hereby, this work contributes to the ever-growing evidence that intertemporal choice is a highly context-dependent phenomenon that is more variable than the initial picture of stable individual time preferences suggested.

figure.head: Figure 1 :
figure.figDesc: Screenshot of the experimental task. The stimuli consisted of monetary and temporal information for two decision options. The stimuli were presented in four quadrants of the screen.

figure.head: Figure 3 :
figure.figDesc: A) Large/late (LL) choice percentages for target trials after small/soon (SS) and large/late bias trials. B) Response times in target trials for choice switches and repetitions. C)Response times for small/soon and large/late choices in target trials.

figure.head: Figure 4 :
figure.figDesc: Choice repetition data. A) Percentage of large/late (LL) choices in target trials for each bias type (SS: small/soon). B) Response times in target trials thatwere a switch or a repetition of the choice made in the previous bias trial.

figure.head: Figure 5 .
figure.figDesc: Attentional measures of choice repetition. A) Selection bias scores in target trials after small/soon (SS) and large/late (LL) bias trials. The selection bias score is a measure of relative attention based on fixation frequencies (-1: only fixations on LL; 0: equal number of fixations on small/soon and LL; 1: only fixations on SS). B) Number of fixations on areas of interest containing temporal information (time dimension) or monetary information (value dimension) in target trials after small/soon (blue) or large/late (red) bias trials.

figure.head: Figure 6 :
figure.figDesc: Attentional choice biases. A) Number of fixations on monetary (value) areas of interest (AOIs) and temporal (time) AOIs. B) Selection bias score for small/soon (SS) and large/late (LL) choices. C) Percentage of large/late choices for trials where the last fixation was on small/soon or on LL. C) Response times in target trials with small/soon or large/late choice.

body.note: This experimental manipulation was only possible for indifference points in the range of 0.3 to 0.7, which is why the experiment terminated automatically after the measurement part if participants either discounted too strongly (indifference points below 0.3) or too weakly (indifference points above 0.7).

div.head: Acknowledgment:
div.p: We thank Paula Marie Henneberg, Josephine Thoß, Wiebke Söllig and Julia Elena Stocker for their help with data collection and data preprocessing.
